name: The Ultimate Almost Famous Quiz |      Movies

questions.text: Early in the film, Lester Bangs (played by Philip Seymour Hoffman) is shown bad-mouthing The Doors during a radio interview.  What band -- whose logo adorns the t-shirt he is wearing -- does he offer up as being 'better' than The Doors?
questions.explanation:
The Guess Who.

	As a Doors fan, I took some exception with this scene...but I'll let it go, since I also like The Guess Who. =)

questions.text: Anita Miller leaves home at age eighteen to become a stewardess. In lieu of a verbal explanation for this departure, she plays a Simon and Garfunkel song as a way of expressing to her mother why she is leaving. What song is it?
questions.explanation:
'America'.

	The lyrics of the song detail the travels of an aimlessly wandering couple.

questions.text: Anita leaves a stack of albums for her younger brother William under his bed. What is the FIRST one that he sees upon discovering the stash?
options: 'Are You Experienced,' by Jimi Hendrix and The Experience
questions.explanation:
'Pet Sounds,' by The Beach Boys.

	A highly influential album of the times...and yet we never hear a single track from it in the movie.

questions.text: William Miller manages to persuade the members of Stillwater to give him a backstage pass by complimenting their work, and showing them that he is truly a fan of the band. What word does he use to describe Russell Hammond's guitar work?
questions.explanation:
incendiary.

	Jeff Bebe is quick to add, 'Hey, I'm incendiary, too!'

questions.text: Jeff Bebe, Stillwater's lead singer, almost never calls William Miller by his name. What, instead, does he call him?
questions.explanation:
enemy & the enemy.

	Journalists, to Jeff, represent the enemies of rock music.

questions.text: Penny Lane (Kate Hudson) tells William that she plans to live abroad for a year, and even invites him to join her. Where does she plan to live?
questions.explanation:
Morocco.

	At the end of the film, we see that Penny does indeed board a plane to Morocco...by herself.

questions.text: The members of Stillwater are from Michigan. What city, specifically, are they from?
questions.explanation:
Troy.

	They are always introduced on stage as hailing from Troy, Michigan.

questions.text: How much is William Miller to be compensated for his Stillwater article by 'Rolling Stone' magazine?
questions.explanation:
$1,000.

	Ben Fong-Torres (Terry Chen) initially offers William $700...but he then mistakes William's shocked silence for some kind of negotiating tactic, and ups the fee to $1,000.

questions.text: When Russell Hammond (Billy Crudup) proclaims, 'I am a golden god!', what state is he in?
questions.explanation:
Kansas.

	The house party Russell and William attend is in Topeka, Kansas.

questions.text: At one point in the film, the entire complement of Stillwater's tour bus rather unexpectedly sings along, in unison, with a song on the radio. Who was the song recorded by?
questions.explanation:
Elton John.

	It was Elton John's 'Tiny Dancer.' (Am I the only person who sings it as, 'Hold me closer, Tony Danza'?)

questions.text: William's mother Elaine is a college professor, but we're never told exactly what she teaches. If we take the one lecture we see her giving as a clue, though, what subject does she MOST LIKELY teach?
questions.explanation:
Psychology.

	Elaine is discussing psychologist Carl Jung the one time we see her lecturing.

questions.text: William asks Penny Lane, 'Don't you have any normal friends?' Finish her response: 'Famous people are just more _________.'
questions.explanation:
interesting.

	Penny is, oddly enough, urinating during this exchange.

questions.text: The members of Stillwater have a special name for their tour bus. What is it?
questions.explanation:
Doris.

	The band is reluctant to leave Doris behind in lieu of the private jet offered up by the record company...but eventually, they do exactly that.  They later regret that decision!

questions.text: What was Stillwater's original name?
questions.explanation:
The Jeff Bebe Band.

	Jeff (Jason Lee) mentions this during the scene when the Stillwater t-shirts make their first and only appearance.

questions.text: Late in the film, William witnesses Russell okaying the bartering of the Band Aids (Penny Lane and company) to another band for fifty dollars and a case of Heineken. Which band winds up with the Band Aids?
questions.explanation:
Humble Pie.

	Humble Pie featured Peter Frampton, who acted as 'technical consultant' on this film, and even played guitar on some of the Stillwater songs.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT the name of one of the Band Aids?
questions.explanation:
Ruby.

	Polexia, Estrella, and Sapphire were played by Anna Paquin, Bijou Phillips, and Fairuza Balk, respectively.

questions.text: When Stillwater's private jet suffers mechanical failure and seems to be crashing, Russell Hammond begins singing a song. What song is it?
questions.explanation:
'Peggy Sue,' by Buddy Holly.

	Buddy Holly, Ritchie Valens, and The Big Bopper died when their small plane crashed on February 3, 1959 -- a date immortalized by Don McLean's 'American Pie' as 'the day the music died.'

questions.text: Finish this quote from Lester Bangs, the last time in the film that he speaks to William: 'The only true currency in this bankrupt world is what you share with somebody else when you're ________.'
questions.explanation:
uncool & un cool & un-cool.

	Bangs, in the movie, describes both William and himself as being extremely 'uncool.'

questions.text: The person credited with writing the score of 'Almost Famous' was a member of what band?
questions.explanation:
Heart.

	Nancy Wilson, Cameron Crowe's wife, is credited with scoring the film, and was a member of Heart, along with her sister Ann.

questions.text: William, in the last moments of the film, *finally* gets his private interview with Russell Hammond. The first question he asks is, 'What do you love about music?' Finish Russell's response: 'To begin with... _________.'
questions.explanation:
everything.

	These are also the last words of the film.
